docs.snippet: The social network said it would make changes to Trending Topics, including no longer referring to a list of national news sources.

headline.print_headline: In Internal Investigation, Facebook Finds No Anti-Conservative Bias
headline.main: Facebook Says an Investigation Found No Evidence of Bias in a News App

docs.abstract: Facebook says internal probe finds no evidence of continual political bias in selecting news for its Trending Topics app; social network had been accused of  eschewing conservative content.

docs.snippet: The gunman raged against the “filthy ways of the west” and spoke of “Islamic state vengeance,” a United States senator revealed.

headline.print_headline: Gunman in Orlando Posted to Facebook During Nightclub Attack, Lawmaker Says
headline.main: Omar Mateen Posted to Facebook Amid Orlando Attack, Lawmaker Says

docs.abstract: Investigators say Orlando nightclub shooter Omar Mateen used several Facebook accounts to conduct searches on law enforcement agencies and terrorism and to write posts declaring allegiance to Islamic State; Mateen reportedly even searched online for references to massacre while he was busy carrying out worse mass shooting in American history.

docs.snippet: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline.main: Italy Earthquake, Syria War, Facebook: Your Wednesday Briefing

docs.snippet: A Thai military court accepted a case on Tuesday against eight people charged with ridiculing junta leader Prayuth Chan-ocha on Facebook, extending a crackdown against dissent after Thais voted earlier this month to accept a military-backed charte...

headline.print_headline: Thai Military Court Accepts Case Against 'Facebook Eight'
headline.main: Thai Military Court Accepts Case Against 'Facebook Eight'

docs.snippet: In a live video, a young woman showed off a purse and a driver’s license that weren’t her own. Less than a month later, she was charged in a string of bar thefts.

headline.print_headline: Before Larceny Arrest, a ‘Cry for Help’ in a Facebook Video
headline.main: Before a Larceny Arrest, a ‘Cry for Help’ on Facebook

docs.abstract: Michael Wilson Crime Scene column describes how arrest of Shaniah Lord in Manhattan on grand larceny charges was preceded by Facebook Live video that seems to show 19-year-old showing off stolen property; Lord is accused of number of thefts from patrons at various Manhattan bars; notes Lord's sister says Facebook posts, which attempted to portray a glamorous life were, in retrospect, cry for help.

docs.snippet: Trump revealed all of his shortcomings in the debate. But does it matter?
Shimon Peres thought about history. Netanyahu thinks about the next election.

headline.print_headline: Peres and the passing of hope
headline.main: Peres and the Passing of Hope

docs.snippet: A study of 10 million Facebook posts found that American men more likely to swear, express anger and argue; women used kinder yet more assertive language.

headline.main: Women From Venus, Men Still From Mars on Facebook, Study Finds

docs.snippet: The tête-à-tête at Facebook headquarters was an attempt to mend fences with conservatives, and most said it was a step in the right direction.

headline.print_headline: Facebook and Right Make Nice in Meeting
headline.main: For Facebook and Conservatives, a Collegial Meeting in Silicon Valley

docs.abstract: Group of 16 Republican commentators and politicians meet with Facebook chief Mark Zuckerberg and other executives to improve relations; social media site faces controversy over allegedly displaying liberal bias.

docs.snippet: It’s easier to leave Palestinians in limbo waiting for a “peace process” that goes nowhere.

headline.print_headline: Why Israel Still Refuses to Choose
headline.main: Why Israel Still Refuses to Choose
